Determine the total number of cookies available for distribution.
Ascertain the total number of dogs involved in receiving cookies.
Recognize that each cookie is given to only one dog, with no sharing allowed.
Determine the number of possible ways to assign the first cookie to any dog.
Determine the number of possible ways to assign the second cookie to any remaining dog.
Determine the number of possible ways to assign the third cookie to any remaining dog.
Calculate the product of possible ways to distribute each cookie to come up with the total number of distributions.

After selecting 3 dogs, in how many different orders can the 3 cookies be distributed among them?
Multiply the number of ways to choose 3 dogs by the number of ways to distribute the cookies to find the total number of distinct distributions.

Finally, what is the product of the number of ways to choose the set of dogs and the number of ways to distribute the cookies among them?
